section.title: Introduction
section.para: onCourse has powerful tools for searching across every piece of data you have collected. You can search in lists, perform advanced searches on any attribute of the data and use these searches to write scripts and reports. In this chapter we'll start from the simplest tools and then show you more advanced possibilities.

section.title: Lists
section.para: Every list view has a search panel across the bottom.

Typing into the Search bar will retrieve all records that match your input across certain fields. For example, in the Contact list, the text you enter will be found in first name, last name and email address fields.
Searching units of competency

section.title: Find related records
section.para: Find related records is one of the most powerful tools inside onCourse, let you quickly jump from window to window, finding records related to groups of other records. This function is located next to the advanced search in each list view in onCourse.

For example, to locate all the employers of all the students aged 18 to 25 in the last three months of VET programs to send the Employer Satisfaction Survey to you can start by searching for all classes with a particular tag or use the advanced search on VET course flag. Once you have those classes, you can highlight those delivered in the last three months, and select from the find related icon 'Enrolled students'.

caption.para: Finding enrolled students related to a class from the cogwheel menu

section.para: Once the student list has opened, you can search that list of results for students aged 18 to 25. The list view that has opened is in a special mode called 'custom selection' which you can see in the window header bar. This means other searches or filters you run on this window are only inside the special set of results you have created as a list.

With the reduced list of students, you can use the find related icon to select contacts related as Employer. From this new window, you can use the cog wheel to send a message to the student's employers.

note.para: Find related can only be run on a max of 1000 records

section.title: Advanced search query language
section.para: You can construct more powerful Advanced Search queries using the onCourse query language. You can toggle between Basic and Advanced Search by clicking the magnifying glass icon on the left of the search panel. When you are in advanced mode, a plus symbol appears next to the icon.
A simple query consists of a field, followed by an operator, followed by a value:

In the above example, the field is 'title', the operator is 'starts with', and the value is 'Apply'. In the Unit of Competency list this will show you records beginning with 'Apply'. Two or more queries can be linked together with conditional operators.
section.programlisting: title starts with 'Apply' and nationalCode starts with "B"
section.para: In this example, 'and' is the conditional operator that combines the two separate queries. Only records that satisfy both queries are returned.

section.title: Fields
section.para: When you click into the Advanced Search box, a drop-down list of available fields will appear. The fields that are available to use in queries will change depending on which record type you are searching on.

section.title: Operators
section.para: Operators are methods of comparing two entities. The two entities that are being compared are called operands. The first operand appears on the left of the operator, while the second operand appears on the right.

listitem.para: EQUALS returns true if the left hand side equal to the right

Usage:
createdOn = today
NOT EQUAL returns true if the left hand side isn't equal to the right

Usage:
deliveryMode != ONLINE
LESS THAN returns true if the left hand side is less than the right.
LESS THAN can also used with EQUALS to return true if the left is less than or equal too the right

Usage: enrolmentCount < 10
enrolmentCount <= 9
GREATER THAN returns true if the left hand side is greater than the right.
GREATER THAN can be used with EQUALS to return true if the left is greater than or equal to the right

Usage: age > 17
age >= 18
IN will return true if the left exists within the right hand side set.
A set is denoted as a pair of brackets, where each element of the set is separated by a comma.

Usage:
code in ("ABC", "DEF", "GHI")
BEFORE that will return true if the left hand side occurs before the right.

Usage:
createdOn before today
AFTER will return true if the left hand side occurs after the right.

Usage:
createdOn after today
CONTAINS returns true if the left hand side contains the right.

Usage:
name contains "Gardening"
STARTS WITH returns true if the left hand side starts with the right.

Usage:
name starts with "Cooking"
ENDS WITH returns true if the left hand side ends with the right.

Usage:
name ends with "Expert"
NOT reverses the returned value of all of the previous operations.
For example, 'code not contains "Gardening"' with return all courses that has a code that does not contain the string 'Gardening'

Usage:
name not like John
name not contains "Gardening"
name not starts with "Cooking"
name not ends with "Beginners"
The LIKE (~) operator is used to search a field for a specific string pattern.

There are two special wild card characters used with the LIKE operator:
%: the percent sign is used to represent any amount of characters (including zero)
_: the underscore is used to represent exactly one character

Examples of the LIKE operator with wild card characters
name ~ "a%" name like "a%"
finds any record that has a name starting with "a"
name ~ "%a"
finds any record that has a name ending with "a"
name ~ "%ab%"
finds any record that has a name containing "ab"
name ~ "_a%"
finds any record that has a name with "a" as the second letter
name ~ "_%_%_%"
finds any record that has a name with at least a length of 3 characters
name ~ "a%b"
finds any record that has a name starting with "a" and ending with "b"

Usage:
name ~ "Gardening%"

section.title: Conditions
section.para: Conditions can be used to chain multiple queries together to build more complex searches.

listitem.para: The OR condition will return true if either left hand side or right hand side are true.

para.programlisting: name contains "Gardening" or code starts with "GAR"

listitem.para: The AND condition will return true if both the left hand and right hand sides are true.
